plain.en-US: Warms the stomach and supports digestion. Helps with nausea and cold symptoms.

tcm.en-US: Warms the Middle Jiao, disperses cold, and harmonizes the Stomach.

text.en-US: Add 2-3 slices to hot water for tea
Grate into congee or soup
Use moderately if you run warm or have acid reflux.

blurb.en-US: A kitchen staple across China, ginger is commonly used in home cooking to warm dishes and aid digestion.

plain.en-US: Nourishes and supports energy. Gently calming and helps with sleep.

tcm.en-US: Tonifies Qi and Blood, calms the Shen, and strengthens the Spleen.

text.en-US: Add 3-5 dates to hot water or tea
Simmer in soups or congee
Limit if you have excess dampness or feel bloated.

blurb.en-US: Red dates are a beloved tonic in Chinese homes, often added to soups and teas for nourishment.

plain.en-US: Supports eye health and gently nourishes. Good for dryness.

tcm.en-US: Nourishes Liver and Kidney Yin, benefits the eyes, and moistens dryness.

Simmer in soups
Use moderately if you have loose stools or feel cold.

blurb.en-US: A common addition to soups and teas, goji berries are valued for their gentle nourishing properties.

plain.en-US: Gently energizing without the jitters. Cooling and supports mental clarity.

tcm.en-US: Clears heat, promotes urination, and calms the mind while promoting alertness.

text.en-US: Steep in hot (not boiling) water for 2-3 minutes

typical_amount.en-US: 1-2 teaspoons loose leaf or 1 tea bag

text.en-US: Contains caffeine. Avoid late in the day if sensitive to caffeine.

blurb.en-US: Green tea is a daily staple in many Chinese households, enjoyed for its subtle flavor and health benefits.

plain.en-US: Cooling and cleansing. Great for hot weather and skin issues.

tcm.en-US: Clears heat, resolves toxins, and promotes urination to clear dampness.

Add to congee
Use less if you run cold or have weak digestion.

blurb.en-US: Mung bean soup is a classic summer refresher in Cantonese cuisine, valued for its cooling properties.

plain.en-US: Strongly warming and supports circulation. Helps with cold hands and feet.

tcm.en-US: Warms the Kidney Yang, dispels cold, and promotes circulation of Qi and Blood.

text.en-US: Add a pinch to warm drinks or oatmeal
Simmer a stick in tea
Use sparingly if you run hot or have night sweats.

blurb.en-US: Cinnamon has been used in Chinese medicine for thousands of years as a powerful warming herb.

plain.en-US: Moistening and cooling. Excellent for dry coughs and dry skin.

tcm.en-US: Generates fluids, moistens the Lungs, and clears heat.

text.en-US: Eat fresh as a snack
Steam with rock sugar and goji berries
Avoid if you have loose stools or feel very cold.

blurb.en-US: Steamed pear with rock sugar is a beloved home remedy for dry coughs in Chinese households.

plain.en-US: Gentle sweetener that moistens dryness and soothes the throat.

tcm.en-US: Tonifies the Middle Jiao, moistens dryness, and harmonizes other ingredients.

text.en-US: Add to warm (not hot) drinks
Drizzle on porridge or fruit
Avoid if you have excess dampness or feel bloated.

tcm.en-US: Calms the Shen, soothes the Liver Qi, and relaxes tension.

text.en-US: Steep 1-2 teaspoons in hot water for 5 minutes
Avoid if you have ragweed allergies.

blurb.en-US: While not traditionally Chinese, chamomile has been adopted into modern TCM practice for its calming properties.

plain.en-US: Cooling and calming. Good for red eyes, headaches, and stress.

tcm.en-US: Clears heat from the Liver, benefits the eyes, and calms rising Yang.

text.en-US: Steep a small handful in hot water
Combine with goji berries for a classic tea
Use less if you feel cold or have loose stools.

blurb.en-US: Chrysanthemum tea is one of the most popular herbal teas in China, especially in summer.

plain.en-US: Easy to digest and provides gentle, sustained energy.

tcm.en-US: Tonifies Qi, supports the Spleen and Stomach, and generates fluids.

text.en-US: Cook into congee with plenty of water
Steam as a side dish
Generally safe for all constitutions.

blurb.en-US: Rice is the foundation of Chinese cuisine and the base for countless healing dishes.

plain.en-US: Nourishing and warming. Supports brain function and kidney energy.

tcm.en-US: Tonifies Kidney Yang, nourishes the Brain, and moistens the Intestines.

text.en-US: Eat a small handful as a snack
Add to porridge or smoothies
Limit if you have loose stools or run hot.

blurb.en-US: Walnuts are considered brain food in Chinese culture, valued for their resemblance to the brain.

subtitle.en-US: Nourishing breakfast to warm your center

text.en-US: Bring 4 cups water to a boil
Add 1/2 cup rice and 2 slices fresh ginger
Reduce heat and simmer, stirring occasionally
Add salt to taste and top with scallions
Eat slowly, savoring the warmth

one_line.en-US: Congee is easily digestible and warming to the center.

plain.en-US: The long cooking breaks down the rice, making nutrients readily available. Ginger adds warming properties that support digestion.

tcm.en-US: Congee supports the Spleen and Stomach, which are responsible for transforming food into usable energy (Qi). Morning warmth protects digestive fire.

text.en-US: Slice 3-4 thin pieces of fresh ginger
Place in a mug and pour hot water over
Let steep for 3-5 minutes
Add honey to taste and sip slowly

one_line.en-US: Fresh ginger tea warms the stomach and supports digestion.

plain.en-US: The honey adds gentle sweetness and has soothing properties. Best consumed warm, not hot.

tcm.en-US: Ginger warms the Middle Jiao and helps disperse cold. Honey moistens and harmonizes.

avoid_notes.en-US: Avoid cold drinks for 2 hours to preserve warming effect

text.en-US: Use less ginger if you have acid reflux.

cue.en-US: Stand with feet hip-width apart, arms relaxed
Inhale, rise halfway with flat back
Inhale, roll up slowly, arms rising

one_line.en-US: Gentle movement in the morning wakes up your body and gets energy flowing.

plain.en-US: Stretching and breathing help release overnight tension and prepare your body for the day.

tcm.en-US: Morning movement helps circulate Qi that can become stagnant during sleep. Twists support the Liver's function of ensuring smooth flow.

text.en-US: Move gently and don't force any positions.
In TCM, 'cold' and 'heat' don't just refer to temperature—they describe patterns in how your body functions.
Someone who 'runs cold' might feel chilly easily, prefer warm drinks, and have slower digestion. Someone who 'runs hot' might feel warm, prefer cool drinks, and have a faster metabolism.
These patterns aren't fixed—they can change with seasons, stress, and lifestyle.

bullets.en-US: Cold signs: feeling chilly, pale complexion, preferring warm drinks, loose stools
Heat signs: feeling warm, flushed face, preferring cool drinks, constipation

one_line.en-US: Understanding your temperature tendency helps you choose foods and habits that balance your body.

text.en-US: In TCM, 'dampness' and 'dryness' describe your body's moisture balance—not just how thirsty you feel.
Dampness shows up as heaviness, puffiness, or sluggish digestion. You might feel foggy-headed or notice sticky stools. Dryness appears as dry skin, lips, or throat, and sometimes constipation.
Your environment matters too—humid climates can increase dampness, while dry, heated rooms can worsen dryness.

bullets.en-US: Damp signs: feeling heavy, puffy, bloated, foggy-headed, sticky stools
Dry signs: dry skin, dry throat, thirst, constipation, dry eyes

one_line.en-US: Knowing your moisture tendency helps you choose foods that restore balance—drying foods for dampness, moistening foods for dryness.

text.en-US: Shen is often translated as 'spirit' or 'mind'—but in TCM, it's more specific. It refers to your mental clarity, emotional balance, and quality of sleep.
When your Shen is settled, you feel calm, focused, and sleep deeply. When it's unsettled, you might feel anxious, scattered, or have trouble falling or staying asleep.
The Heart 'houses' the Shen in TCM. That's why heart-calming practices help with sleep and anxiety.

bullets.en-US: Settled Shen: good sleep, calm mind, emotional resilience, clear thinking
Unsettled Shen: racing thoughts, anxiety, insomnia, vivid dreams, easily startled

one_line.en-US: Calming the Shen isn't just about relaxation—it's about creating conditions for deep rest and mental clarity.

text.en-US: Qi is often translated as 'energy,' but that oversimplifies it. Think of Qi as your body's functional capacity—the ability to do, move, and transform.
When Qi flows smoothly, you feel energized and emotionally balanced. When Qi gets stuck (stagnates), you might feel irritable, tense, or notice sighing and chest tightness.
Stress is the #1 cause of Qi stagnation. Movement, breath, and aromatic foods help get things flowing again.

bullets.en-US: Smooth Qi: steady energy, even mood, good digestion, flexibility
Stuck Qi: irritability, tension, sighing, feeling 'stuck,' PMS symptoms

one_line.en-US: Moving stuck Qi is one of the most immediate ways to feel better—a walk, some stretches, or aromatic tea can help.

text.en-US: How you prepare food matters as much as what you eat. Warming methods add heat energy to foods, making them easier to digest and better for cold constitutions.
Cooking methods like simmering, stewing, roasting, and sautéing add warmth. Even room-temperature foods are warmer than cold ones straight from the fridge.

bullets.en-US: Most warming: grilling, roasting, long simmering
Moderately warming: sautéing, steaming, short boiling

one_line.en-US: If you run cold, simply cooking your food more thoroughly can make a real difference—try avoiding raw salads and cold drinks.

text.en-US: If you run warm, how you prepare food can help cool you down—without going to extremes like ice-cold drinks (which can actually cause problems).
Light cooking methods like quick steaming, blanching, or eating foods at room temperature preserve cooling properties. Raw foods are cooling, but only if your digestion is strong.
Ice-cold drinks can shock your system. Room temperature or cool (not icy) is better for true cooling.

bullets.en-US: Cooling foods: cucumber, mung bean, watermelon, pear, chrysanthemum
Cooling methods: raw (if digestion is strong), steaming, blanching
Avoid: overly spicy, fried, or grilled foods when you're too warm

one_line.en-US: Gentle cooling is more sustainable than extreme cold—your body will thank you.

superpower.en-US: When you're consistent, you become steady. Warmth and routine unlock your best energy.

trap.en-US: Cold inputs and skipping meals drain you faster than you expect.

signature_ritual.en-US: Warm start within 30 minutes of waking.

truths.en-US: Your system does better with gentle build-up than big pushes.
Cooked food stabilizes you—raw/cold hits harder for you than most.
Movement works best for you when it warms you up, not when it exhausts you.

superpower.en-US: You adapt well. With the right ritual, you can fine-tune sleep, digestion, and energy quickly.

trap.en-US: When your schedule gets chaotic, your body follows.

signature_ritual.en-US: A daily anchor: one warm drink + one short movement.

truths.en-US: You're responsive—small routines keep you aligned.
Your biggest lever is consistency, not strictness.
You can tolerate variety, but your body loves rhythm.

superpower.en-US: You have intensity. When it's directed, you're powerful and sharp.

trap.en-US: You can overrun your nervous system—sleep becomes the first casualty.

signature_ritual.en-US: A nightly downshift: breath + screens off.

truths.en-US: Your body runs hot under stress.
You need deliberate cooling signals, not more stimulation.
Your best days start with calm, not urgency.
